column4: Can I connect my Ubuntu 7.10 computer to a Windows XP computer through a firect CAT5 cable to transfer files?
it's cat5 cable with some wires swapped in order to connect to ethernet cards together rather than an ethernet card to a hub/switch/router
you check if the wires coloring is replicated at both ends
you will have to setup a static IP configuration on both machines.
an internet protocol connection where you input the parameters manually.
control panel, network connections, right click, properties, tcp/ip, properties
that won't work unless you have a DHCP server on the linux machine you're connecting to.
use 192.168.0.1 as the ip address on one machine, and 192.168.0.2 on the other
you don't have a DNS server, so leave that alone
i know how to do it by editing /etc/network/interfaces, but there's something called Network Manager on Ubuntu by default, which kind of gets in the way. i don't know the GNOME way either
if you already know how to transfer files... from the console, it's "sudo mount //192.168.0.1/SomeWindowsSharedFolderName /Some/Directory/On/Linux -o username=you"... from GNOME, no idea
assuming you gave 192.168.0.1 to the windows machine, that is
